title: CSCEC donates disaster relief supplies to Damerdjog after Cyclone Sagar
description: On June 12, 2018, China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) donated disaster relief supplies to the Damerdjog Village Government in Djibouti. The donated supplies included 16,250 kilograms of rice, 13,000 kilograms of sugar, 3,250 liters of cooking oil, and 1,300 T-shirts. It did so after 650 households in the area were left homeless by storms. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  The donation was made in responded to Cyclone Sagar which hit Djibouti in May 2018 and affected thousands of people through heavy rains and ensuing floods.
staff_comments: The French project title [Sic] is Donation charitable organise para CSCEC Djibouti SARL.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
CSCEC donates disaster relief supplies to Damerdjog after Cyclone Sagar

# Description
On June 12, 2018, China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) donated disaster relief supplies to the Damerdjog Village Government in Djibouti. The donated supplies included 16,250 kilograms of rice, 13,000 kilograms of sugar, 3,250 liters of cooking oil, and 1,300 T-shirts. It did so after 650 households in the area were left homeless by storms. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  The donation was made in responded to Cyclone Sagar which hit Djibouti in May 2018 and affected thousands of people through heavy rains and ensuing floods.
justification: Project is focused on disaster relief and humanitarian aid without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of food and clothing supplies to cyclone-affected community, no energy or infrastructure components

title: China Merchants Group provides $7 million grant for Social Housing Project
description: On July 4, 2018, at a project commencement ceremony, China Merchants Group (CMG) — a Chinese state-owned company — announced that it was providing a $7 million grant to the Omar Guelleh (IOG) Foundation for a Social Housing Project. The purpose of the project is to create 1,000 social housing (two bedroom) units for vulnerable households in the Balbala district, in the southern suburbs of Djibouti city.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as Project Nassib. 2. Under direct supervision of the State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council, CMG is a conglomerate with three business platforms of non-financial industries, financial services, investment and capital operation. CMG's non-financial industries cover ports, toll roads, shipping, logistics, real estate, zone development, offshore engineering and trade. 3. The Social Housing Project is being financed as part of the CMG’s corporate social responsibility (CSR) activities, so for the time being AidData assumes that CMG is responsible for project implementation.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China Merchants Group provides $7 million grant for Social Housing Project

# Description
On July 4, 2018, at a project commencement ceremony, China Merchants Group (CMG) — a Chinese state-owned company — announced that it was providing a $7 million grant to the Omar Guelleh (IOG) Foundation for a Social Housing Project. The purpose of the project is to create 1,000 social housing (two bedroom) units for vulnerable households in the Balbala district, in the southern suburbs of Djibouti city.
justification: Project focuses on social housing for vulnerable populations without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Social housing units for vulnerable households, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides training on surveillance camera systems for 29 Djiboutian public security agents (Linked to Project ID#59548)
description: To support the Djibouti City Security Surveillance System Project, which received grant funding from the Chinese Government and sought to construct a surveillance system for Djibouti City (see linked project ID#59548), in May 2018, the Chinese Government hosted a one-month long seminar and training program on surveillance camera systems for 29 Djiboutian public security agents. Further details are unknown.

# Title

title: China Merchants Port Holdings Company Limited provides provide 6-month maturity extension on $150 million supplier's credit for Djibouti International Free Trade Zone (DIFTZ) Expansion Project (Linked to Project ID#85139, 59393)
description: On March 24, 2015, Hu Jianhua, General Manager of China Merchants Group (CMG), and the President of Djibouti signed a cooperation framework agreement for a free trade zone (FTZ). Then on January 18, 2016, CMG and the Djibouti Port and Free Trade Zone Authority (DPFZA) held a signing ceremony for a framework agreement for the Djibouti International Free Trade Zone (DIFTZ) Expansion Project. CMG then signed a project contract on January 15, 2017. Three days later, on January 18, 2017, Khor Ambado Free Zone Co. (FZCO or Djibouti Asset Company) — a special purpose vehicle and joint venture between Port of Dalian Authority Group (10% equity stake), China Merchants Shekou Industrial Zone Holdings (招商局蛇口工业区控股股份有限公司) (6% equity stake), China Merchants Investment Development Co., Ltd (CMID) (12% ownership stake), China Merchants Port Holdings Co., Ltd (12% ownership stake), and the Djibouti Ports & Free Zones Authority (DPFZA) (60% equity stake) — was established (legally incorporated) to develop commercial and infrastructure projects within the Djibouti International Free Trade Zone (DIFTZ). Then, on November 10, 2017, China Merchants Port Holdings Company Limited (CMP) issued a $150 million supplier’s credit (‘CMP Loan Facility’) agreement with Khor Ambado Free Zone Co. for the Djibouti International Free Trade Zone (DIFTZ) Expansion Project. The CMP loan, captured via Project ID#59393, carried the following borrowing terms: a 5% annual interest rate, a 1.25-year maturity (with the option to extend the maturity by 8.75 additional years), and no grace period.     The Government of Djibouti — through the state-owned Djibouti Port and Free Trade Zone Authority (DPFZA) — issued a sovereign guarantee for repaying the supplier's credit. The loan was collateralized by a share pledge over 15.3% of the shares held by Great Horn Investment Holdings SAS (a subsidiary of DPFZA) in a China-Djibouti joint venture called Port De Djibouti S.A., which is co-owned the Government of Djibouti (76.5% equity stake) and China Merchants Port Holdings Company Ltd. (23.5% equity stake). Khor Ambado Free Zone Co. used the supplier's credit (loan) facility to on-lend to Port De Djibouti S.A. (PDSA).  Then, in 2019, China Development Bank and Khor Ambado Free Zone Co. signed a $240 million loan agreement (ID#4430201901100002407) for the Djibouti International Free Trade Zone (DIFTZ) Expansion Project. The CDB loan, which is captured via Project ID#85139, carried the following borrowing terms: a 13 year maturity and a 3 year grace period. China Merchants Shekou Industrial Zone Holdings Co., Ltd. provided a loan guarantee worth $14.4 million (6% of $240 million CDB loan). The Government of Djibouti provided a sovereign guarantee for 60% of the face value of the loan ($144 million). The DIFTZ is a 40-hectare zone that consists of three functional blocks located close to all of Djibouti’s major ports.     The purpose of the DIFTZ is to support industries such as the logistics, marine, construction, automotive, and home electrical industries. It is equipped with advanced facilities including high-speed telecommunications, power and water supplies, roads and parking lots. The pilot zone has four industrial clusters which focus on trade and logistics, export processing and business support: (1) Logistics Industry Cluster: transportation, bonded warehousing, logistics and distribution; (2) Business Industry Cluster: bulk bonded goods transactions, merchandise display, duty-free merchandise retail; (3) Business Support Cluster: financial services, information services, hotel dormitories, office buildings, training, intermediary services; and (4) Processing Manufacturing Cluster: packaging production, light processing of incoming materials, food processing, marine products, auto parts assembly.     China Merchants Holdings (Djibouti) FZE (“CM Djibouti”) was the company responsible for project implementation. On January 16, 2017, Djiboutian President Guelleh and General Manager of China Merchants Group Hu Jianhua unveiled the launch area and laid a foundation stone for the DIFTZ expansion project. The first phase of the project, which involved upgrading and expanding the port facilities of DIFTZ, was officially opened on July 5, 2018.  There are some indications that the $150 million CMP loan for the DIFTZ expansion project financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. In September 2018, the Government of Djibouti nationalized the Dolareh Container Terminal (DCT), an asset held by PDSA. The change in DCT ownership affected PDSA's expected profits because PDSA's profits included dividend receivables from DCT. As a result, the potential chargeable interest on the CMP loan facility, which would be determined in part by PDSA profits, was rendered invalid. The DCT nationalization also affected DPFZA's share pledge value. On November 9, 2018, CMP extended the loan's final maturity date by another 6 months (as captured via Project ID#97763).
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Merchants Port Holdings Company Limited provides provide 6-month maturity extension on $150 million supplier's credit for Djibouti International Free Trade Zone (DIFTZ) Expansion Project (Linked to Project ID#85139, 59393)

# Description
On March 24, 2015, Hu Jianhua, General Manager of China Merchants Group (CMG), and the President of Djibouti signed a cooperation framework agreement for a free trade zone (FTZ). Then on January 18, 2016, CMG and the Djibouti Port and Free Trade Zone Authority (DPFZA) held a signing ceremony for a framework agreement for the Djibouti International Free Trade Zone (DIFTZ) Expansion Project. CMG then signed a project contract on January 15, 2017. Three days later, on January 18, 2017, Khor Ambado Free Zone Co. (FZCO or Djibouti Asset Company) — a special purpose vehicle and joint venture between Port of Dalian Authority Group (10% equity stake), China Merchants Shekou Industrial Zone Holdings (招商局蛇口工业区控股股份有限公司) (6% equity stake), China Merchants Investment Development Co., Ltd (CMID) (12% ownership stake), China Merchants Port Holdings Co., Ltd (12% ownership stake), and the Djibouti Ports & Free Zones Authority (DPFZA) (60% equity stake) — was established (legally incorporated) to develop commercial and infrastructure projects within the Djibouti International Free Trade Zone (DIFTZ). Then, on November 10, 2017, China Merchants Port Holdings Company Limited (CMP) issued a $150 million supplier’s credit (‘CMP Loan Facility’) agreement with Khor Ambado Free Zone Co. for the Djibouti International Free Trade Zone (DIFTZ) Expansion Project. The CMP loan, captured via Project ID#59393, carried the following borrowing terms: a 5% annual interest rate, a 1.25-year maturity (with the option to extend the maturity by 8.75 additional years), and no grace period.     The Government of Djibouti — through the state-owned Djibouti Port and Free Trade Zone Authority (DPFZA) — issued a sovereign guarantee for repaying the supplier's credit. The loan was collateralized by a share pledge over 15.3% of the shares held by Great Horn Investment Holdings SAS (a subsidiary of DPFZA) in a China-Djibouti joint venture called Port De Djibouti S.A., which is co-owned the Government of Djibouti (76.5% equity stake) and China Merchants Port Holdings Company Ltd. (23.5% equity stake). Khor Ambado Free Zone Co. used the supplier's credit (loan) facility to on-lend to Port De Djibouti S.A. (PDSA).  Then, in 2019, China Development Bank and Khor Ambado Free Zone Co. signed a $240 million loan agreement (ID#4430201901100002407) for the Djibouti International Free Trade Zone (DIFTZ) Expansion Project. The CDB loan, which is captured via Project ID#85139, carried the following borrowing terms: a 13 year maturity and a 3 year grace period. China Merchants Shekou Industrial Zone Holdings Co., Ltd. provided a loan guarantee worth $14.4 million (6% of $240 million CDB loan). The Government of Djibouti provided a sovereign guarantee for 60% of the face value of the loan ($144 million). The DIFTZ is a 40-hectare zone that consists of three functional blocks located close to all of Djibouti’s major ports.     The purpose of the DIFTZ is to support industries such as the logistics, marine, construction, automotive, and home electrical industries. It is equipped with advanced facilities including high-speed telecommunications, power and water supplies, roads and parking lots. The pilot zone has four industrial clusters which focus on trade and logistics, export processing and business support: (1) Logistics Industry Cluster: transportation, bonded warehousing, logistics and distribution; (2) Business Industry Cluster: bulk bonded goods transactions, merchandise display, duty-free merchandise retail; (3) Business Support Cluster: financial services, information services, hotel dormitories, office buildings, training, intermediary services; and (4) Processing Manufacturing Cluster: packaging production, light processing of incoming materials, food processing, marine products, auto parts assembly.     China Merchants Holdings (Djibouti) FZE (“CM Djibouti”) was the company responsible for project implementation. On January 16, 2017, Djiboutian President Guelleh and General Manager of China Merchants Group Hu Jianhua unveiled the launch area and laid a foundation stone for the DIFTZ expansion project. The first phase of the project, which involved upgrading and expanding the port facilities of DIFTZ, was officially opened on July 5, 2018.  There are some indications that the $150 million CMP loan for the DIFTZ expansion project financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. In September 2018, the Government of Djibouti nationalized the Dolareh Container Terminal (DCT), an asset held by PDSA. The change in DCT ownership affected PDSA's expected profits because PDSA's profits included dividend receivables from DCT. As a result, the potential chargeable interest on the CMP loan facility, which would be determined in part by PDSA profits, was rendered invalid. The DCT nationalization also affected DPFZA's share pledge value. On November 9, 2018, CMP extended the loan's final maturity date by another 6 months (as captured via Project ID#97763).
justification: Project focuses on development of a free trade zone with mixed commercial and industrial infrastructure, without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Development of 40-hectare free trade zone with logistics, business, and processing clusters; includes general infrastructure like roads, parking, and utilities

title: China Grants 19 Vehicles Worth USD $1.6M to Dominica for Hurricane Maria Relief (Linked to ID#55319 and ID#55325)
description: China donated 19 military vehicles, which included a fire truck, ambulances, cargo trucks and so on, as well as materials for these vehicles and the equipment for repairing these materials at a sum of $1.6 million. The hand over ceremony was held at the Windsor Park Stadium on April 10th, 2018. This logistic material aid was expected to enhance Dominica's capacity in areas of recovery, disaster reduction and maintaining stability in a medical emergency.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China Grants 19 Vehicles Worth USD $1.6M to Dominica for Hurricane Maria Relief (Linked to ID#55319 and ID#55325)

# Description
China donated 19 military vehicles, which included a fire truck, ambulances, cargo trucks and so on, as well as materials for these vehicles and the equipment for repairing these materials at a sum of $1.6 million. The hand over ceremony was held at the Windsor Park Stadium on April 10th, 2018. This logistic material aid was expected to enhance Dominica's capacity in areas of recovery, disaster reduction and maintaining stability in a medical emergency.
justification: Project focuses on emergency response and disaster relief, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of military vehicles and equipment for disaster recovery and medical emergencies

title: Chinese Navy hospital ship Ark Peace visits Dominica
description: On October 12, 2018, Chinese navy hospital ship Ark Peace, which is on the "Harmonious Mission 2018", arrived at the Port of Roseau of Dominica for an eight-day friendly visit. It carried out a series of activities during the visit, including offering free medical services to 5000 local people and staff of Chinese-funded institutions, providing medical training and holding cultural entertainment events.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Navy hospital ship Ark Peace visits Dominica

# Description
On October 12, 2018, Chinese navy hospital ship Ark Peace, which is on the "Harmonious Mission 2018", arrived at the Port of Roseau of Dominica for an eight-day friendly visit. It carried out a series of activities during the visit, including offering free medical services to 5000 local people and staff of Chinese-funded institutions, providing medical training and holding cultural entertainment events.
justification: Project is focused on providing healthcare services and cultural exchange, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Hospital ship providing free medical services, medical training, and cultural events

title: Chinese Government donates supplies to Newtown Primary School
description: On September 26, 2018, Chinese Ambassador Kun Lu paid a visit to Newtown Primary School and made a donation of a batch of stationery supplies to the school. The stationery supplies include basketball, basketball stands, table tennis tables, table tennis paddles, flying discs, jumping ropes, clarinets, whiteboard, etc.

title: China Conducts Seventh Phase of China-Aided Dominica Agricultural Technical Cooperation Project (Linked to Project ID #56148 and #98408)
description: On 10 May, 2018, China started the seventh phase of Dominica agricultural technical cooperation project (援多米尼克第七期农业技术合作项目). It is expected to end in 2021. This phase includes helping farmers recover from the damage caused by a series of hurricanes. As of July 17, 2020, 15 greenhouses have been restored; a new drainage system has been installed; and like previous phases, new crop varieties have been introduced; new hardware given; and farmers given new training. Additionally, 300,000 quality seedlings have been cultivated, and over a dozen demonstration trials for vegetables, flowers and fruit trees conducted.   The seventh phase would completed on May 10, 2021.
staff_comments: Project #56148 seems to cover Phase six, but also it seems to aggregate all first six phases into one project. Linked Facebook video where officials from the Chinese Economic and Commercial Office at Dominica give an update seventh phase's progress, the presentation starts at the 51:00 min mark. During the project history portion of the presentation, which is at the beginning, the Chinese official said that the seventh phase is a continuation of the overall project. There were no indications that financing came from a different agreement (see 'The seventh phase...').
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
China Conducts Seventh Phase of China-Aided Dominica Agricultural Technical Cooperation Project (Linked to Project ID #56148 and #98408)

# Description
On 10 May, 2018, China started the seventh phase of Dominica agricultural technical cooperation project (援多米尼克第七期农业技术合作项目). It is expected to end in 2021. This phase includes helping farmers recover from the damage caused by a series of hurricanes. As of July 17, 2020, 15 greenhouses have been restored; a new drainage system has been installed; and like previous phases, new crop varieties have been introduced; new hardware given; and farmers given new training. Additionally, 300,000 quality seedlings have been cultivated, and over a dozen demonstration trials for vegetables, flowers and fruit trees conducted.   The seventh phase would completed on May 10, 2021.
justification: Project focuses on agricultural development and recovery from natural disasters without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Greenhouse restoration, drainage system installation, crop variety introduction, farmer training, seedling cultivation, demonstration trials

title: Dominica Agricultural Industrial and Development Bank borrows EC$1.119 million from China Eximbank to support on-lending activities
description: In Fiscal Year 2018, Dominica Agricultural Industrial and Development Bank — a bank that is majority-owned by the Government of the Commonwealth of Dominica (GOCD) — borrowed EC$1,119,604 from China Eximbank to support on-lending activities. The loan was guaranteed by the GOCD.
staff_comments: 1. The 2018 annual report of the Dominica Agricultural Industrial and Development Bank identifies the ‘Republic of China’ as the lender. However, given that Dominica severed diplomatic ties with Taiwan in May 2004, the lender is almost certainly the People’s Republic of China (PRC). Reporting by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) corroborates the existence of a lending relationship between the PRC and Dominica Agricultural Industrial and Development Bank. 2. The precise financial commitment date is unknown. However, it is known that the EC$1,119,604 borrowing took place between July 1, 2017 and June 30, 2018. 3. For evidence that the lender is China Eximbank, see https://www.dropbox.com/s/jwlm7akcczpmbgr/New%20AID%20Bank%20Chairman%20outlines%20plans%20for%20the%20bank%20-%20GIS%20Dominica.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/jntz051chitv5pp/Rationale%20-%20Dominica%20AID%20Bank%20June%204%2C%202013%282%29.pdf?dl=0. 4. This China Eximbank loan is not captured in the China-Latin America Finance Database, which is co-produced by the Inter-American Dialogue and Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center.
combined_text:
# Sector
BANKING AND FINANCIAL SERVICES

# Title
Dominica Agricultural Industrial and Development Bank borrows EC$1.119 million from China Eximbank to support on-lending activities

# Description
In Fiscal Year 2018, Dominica Agricultural Industrial and Development Bank — a bank that is majority-owned by the Government of the Commonwealth of Dominica (GOCD) — borrowed EC$1,119,604 from China Eximbank to support on-lending activities. The loan was guaranteed by the GOCD.
justification: Project involves financial services with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Loan for on-lending activities through a development bank, no specific environmental or energy-related purpose mentioned
